) Editorial changes made throughout this IRM to update titles, grammar, and
Editorial changes made throughout this IRM to update titles, grammar, and punctuation.
EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS
IRM 3.24.159, dated October 6, 2015 (effective January 1, 2018) is superseded. IPU 21U0827 issued 06-10- 2021, IPU 21U0936 issued 07-14-2021.
Wage and Investment Submission Processing Integrated Submission and Remittance Processing operators
Table of Contents

) Purpose: The Integrated Submission and Remittance Processing System (ISRP) is used to process forms and remittances. Data is entered, processed and fed to other IRS systems. This chapter provided instructions for the Original Entry, Key VeriÔ¨Åcation, and Block Edit of tax returns and related data through ISRP. a. This section describes the way data from Integrated Submission and Remittance Processing System (ISRP), lockbox, mag tape, and the Service Center Recognition Image Processing System (SCRIPS) is validated and edited. It provides detailed information for the preparation of edit parameters; and designates responsibility for the initial implemen- tation as well as periodic updating of the Edit System. Parameters for Data Edit and Validation (DED) are also used by ISRP (Common Services). (
) Audience: The primary users of this IRM are Submission Processing employees; ISRP clerks and managers. (
) Policy Owner: The Director of Submission Processing. (
) Program Owner: Paper Processing Branch, Mail Management / Data sion Section. (
) Primary Stakeholder: Management officials who rely on accurate data gathered by the ISRP Program. (

) The Integrated Submission and Remittance Processing (ISRP) System tran- scribes and formats data from paper returns/documents/vouchers for input the Generalized Mainline Framework (GMF) and other systems by key entry operators. It also captures check images for archiving. Transaction Manage- ment System (TMS) is a COTS product that is an integral part of ISRP. (

) The following provides authority for the instructions in this IRM to be performed in support of completing compliance functions to make credits or refunds of any internal revenue tax, processing of non-revenue forms, and ministrative support forms. a. Title
of the United States Code (USC) or more commonly known the Internal Revenue Code (IRC). b. All Policy Statements for Submission Processing are contained in IRM

, Servicewide Policies and Authorities, Policy Statements for mission Processing Activities: ‚Ä¢ Code sections which provide the IRS with the authority to issue levies. ‚Ä¢ Congressional Acts which outline additional authorities and responsibili- ties like the Travel and Transportation Reform Act of
or the Tax Reform Act of
‚Ä¢ Policy Statements that provide authority for the work being done. (
) The Operations manager is responsible for securing, assigning and providing training for the staff needed to perform the task required throughout this in- struction.

This section describes the way data from Integrated Submission and Remittance Processing System (ISRP), lockbox, mag tape, and the Service Center Recognition Image Processing System (SCRIPS) is validated and edited. It provides detailed information for the preparation of edit parameters; and designates responsibility for the initial implemen
tation as well as periodic updating of the Edit System. Parameters for the Data Edit and Validation (DED) are also used by ISRP (Common Services).
Title
of the United States Code (USC) or more commonly known as the Internal Revenue Code (IRC). All Policy Statements for Submission Processing are contained in IRM
, Servicewide Policies and Authorities, Policy Statements for Sub- mission Processing Activities:
) The Planning and Analysis Staff is responsible for providing feedback and support to local management to achieve and effectively monitor scheduled goals. (
) The team manager is responsible for assigning, monitoring and controlling work Ô¨Çow to accomplish timely completion of the tasks required throughout IRM. (

) The employee is responsible for applying the instruction present to the assigned task on the ISRP system to accurately convert paper data to elec- tronic data record for proper posting for use by the Service. Management (

) Program Reports: Below are a list of reports to use to show receipts, tion and inventory for the paper return to electronic data conversion process. These reports will be utilized to report and monitor daily and weekly status the program to completeness. ‚Ä¢ PCC
, SC WP&C Performance and Cost Report ‚Ä¢ PCC
, SC WP&C Program Analysis Report (

) Program Effectiveness: Goals will be measured utilizing standard manage- rial reports by documents processed per hour and completion of each compared to the established schedule for completion each week. Each function is expected to retain or exceed schedule prior to the program tion date stated in IRM

, Processing Timeliness: Cycles, Criteria, Critical Dates. Quality reviews are expected to be conducted and monitored local management and corrective action taken to ensure quality products released to the next function. (
) Annual Review: Review the processes included in this manual annually ensure accuracy and promote consistent tax administration. This may be included under responsibilities for a manager. Controls (
) The reports for the Control Data Analysis, Project PCD, are on the Control-D/ Web Access server, which has a login program control. Terms,DeÔ¨Ånitions/Acronyms (

) The following terms or acronyms are utilized throughout this IRM: Term DeÔ¨Ånition Key VeriÔ¨Åcation (KV) The operators perform quality review on payments through an electronic method called Key VeriÔ¨Åcation. Original Entry (OE) The operators manually key enter data from both scanned images and paper documents. Internal Revenue Manual Cat. No.

) IRM deviations must be submitted in writing following instructions from IRM
, Internal Management Documents System - Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) Process, IRM Standards, and elevated through appropriate channels executive approval. Controls (
) The Federal Managers‚Äô Financial Integrity Act (FMFIA) of
requires executive agency to conduct annual evaluations of its systems of control guidelines set by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB). (
) In December
, OMB issued a revision of Circular Number A-

, Man- agement‚Äôs Responsibility for Internal Control, to provide guidance to federal managers on improving the accountability and effectiveness of federal programs and operations by establishing, assessing, correcting, and reporting on internal control. (
) For speciÔ¨Åc guidelines and responsibilities, refer to the Circular A-
, and IRM
, Management Roles and Responsibilities, and IRM
, Monitoring and Improving Internal Control. (SC) (

) The Service Center Replacement System (SCRS) eliminated the need for customized edits. A multipurpose program has been developed which a generalized edit function for all projects. This program is driven by param- eters which must be supplied by the analyst assigned to each individual project. (

) SCRIPS data is input to the multipurpose program for validation/reject pro- cessing, but it does not undergo further edit processing as it is already in edited format. Data Edit (DED) ISRP Services) (

) Input to the Data Edit and Validation (DED) System and ISRP is through Data Entry, Lockbox, SCRIPS, and magnetic tape. Coordination of data instructions is the responsibility of the ISRP analyst, and the analyst assigned to each individual project. These instructions will govern the format of the into the Edits Processing system. Fields will be edited and output in the order in which they are entered. (
) Since the systems are designed so that input can be in a variety of formats, the general requirements for input are minimal and correspond to the format requirements for ISRP. (
) Each block must contain a block header which consists of: a. Operator Class - See IRM
, Operator Class b. Format Code - See IRM
, Format Code c. Service Center (SC) Block Control Number - See IRM
, Service Center Block Control Number (
) Each block must contain at least one document with a document breaker SC Edits
page (
) Internal Revenue Manual
Each block must contain at least one document with a document breaker ([).
) Each block must contain at least one section with a section breaker (@). (
) Each block must contain at least one Ô¨Åeld per section. (
) Each block must contain an end of block indicator (EOB). (

) When preparing parameters for an input document, comments can be placed on each parameter entry line by separating the end of the parameter and beginning of the comment with at least three spaces. (

) The operator class is a one-digit Ô¨Åeld which may provide additional information on the type of document being entered. Operator class assignment for a document is obtained from the ISRP analyst along with the Format Code. Generally, the Operator Class is assigned as follows: a. Operator Class ‚Äú
‚Äù - used for Individual Master File (IMF) and Business Master File (BMF) mainline documents. b. Operator Class ‚Äú
‚Äù - used for Employee Plan/Management Information System (EP/MIS). c. Operator Class ‚Äú
‚Äù - used for General Purpose Program (GPP). d. Operator Class ‚Äú
‚Äù - used for Information Return Program (IRP) documents read by SCRIPS. (

) A three-digit Format Code must be assigned by the ISRP analyst to each of input document. While the sections within a document may have various formats on both input and output, all documents entered under one Format Code must have like formats. Format (
) The Format Code is a three-digit number ranging from
to
More one type of document (Format Code) can be processed simultaneously through the edit system. (
) The same Format Code may be assigned to more than one type of input document if the input documents have the same identical formats. (
) For assignment of Operator Class/Format Codes, contact the ISRP analyst, OS:IT:AD:SP:PPB. (SC) Number (
) The SC Block Control Number (formerly ABC) is a three-digit/character Sub- mission Processing Site generated code assigned to each block of documents for control purposes. the Data Validation (
) Output from the DED System and ISRP Common Services is governed by parameters supplied for each document. IRM
, Parameters, provides a detailed description of these parameters. In preparing parameters for a document, data sizing limitations are as follows: Maximum Size

) Four problem code Ô¨Åelds (one character each) are established by the edits program for every section, immediately in front of the section number. They in order of occurrence: a. ISRP b. MIXED-DATA c. SECTION d. FIELD (

) These Ô¨Åelds will be zero-Ô¨Ålled if the problem code checks are successfully passed. More information on problem code checks may be found in Functional SpeciÔ¨Åcation Package (FSP) documentation (
Part
, Subpart
, SC Data Edit Prep). (

) The Data Edit and Validation (DED) System also performs certain validation checks to ensure logical processing integrity of all input data blocks. Failure any of these checks will result in the subject block being dropped from further processing. At the same time a line entry will appear on the EDIT REJECT LIST with identifying information, including the block Document Locator Number (DLN) for machine data. For further information on the EDIT REJECT LIST, check FSP
Part
, Subpart
, SC Data Edit Prep. (
) The documentation of user Non-Pipeline programs (programs that receive from Generalized Main Frame (GMF)
) must include a File IdentiÔ¨Åcation starting with other than GMF in their parameters. All Non-Pipeline output will be in interchange format, odd parity,
Bits per Inch (BPI) and have American National Standards Institute (ANSI) labels. (

) The Ô¨Årst Ô¨Åeld, (four numerics), of each output record will always be a record length character count (not including the Ô¨Åeld itself). The receiving program File Description (FD) must have the following: a. RECORD CONTAINS (greater than or equal to)
to
b. RECORDING MODE is ‚ÄúD‚Äù for UNISYS and ‚ÄúV‚Äù for IBM. (
) Multiple Format Codes will be placed on the same Non-Pipeline output Ô¨Åle when: a. The File IdentiÔ¨Åcations are identical, and b. The Operator Class/Format Codes are consecutive (no breaks), as:

The Data Edit and Validation (DED) System also performs certain validation checks to ensure logical processing integrity of all input data blocks. Failure of any of these checks will result in the subject block being dropped from further processing. At the same time a line entry will appear on the EDIT REJECT LIST with identifying information, including the block Document Locator Number (DLN) for machine data. For further information on the EDIT REJECT LIST, check FSP 1.35.00 Part 1, Subpart 2, SC Data Edit Prep.
) The following deÔ¨Åne types of parameters, and their use. (
) There are three types of parameters: a. Document b. Section c. Field (
) Parameters must be entered on the UNISYS system and stored as a symbolic element in a shared program Ô¨Åle. See IRM
, Initial Transmittals, transmittal instructions. (
) As many parameters and types of parameters as desired can be included in the shared program Ô¨Åle. (
) Parameters cannot be split between line entries. Entry is limited to
charac- ters. (
) Three consecutive blanks will cause the remainder of the parameter entry to be treated as a comment. (
) The character ‚Äú@‚Äù can never be the Ô¨Årst character of an entry. (
) Only requirement parameters need be entered. (
) If a parameter is not required to be present and no entry has been made for that parameter, in general, the default value generated will produce record matting in GMF format. (
) One set (and one set only) of document parameters must be prepared for each Format Code. (
) Exhibit
, Document Parameters, shows the format and speciÔ¨Åcations for the document parameters. The following is a description of the various elements and options.

Exception: a) IRP documents must have the Ô¨Årst Ô¨Åve characters coded as ‚ÄúGMF07 ‚Äù. b) For Non-Pipeline data, this is a 12-character value used in the ‚ÄúFILE-ID IS...‚Äù clause of the user program‚Äôs FD statement. The name entered in this parameter will be expanded to 12 positions with Ô¨Ålling zeros to the right (EX: EXM0101 will become EXM010100000). Program SELECT statements and ECL,@,ASG statements should be changed to match this Ô¨Åle name. E4 Document Breaker Suppressor Must be present if a document breaker ([) is not desired between documents. If present, must be delimited by the special character ‚Äú>‚Äù. E5 Serial Number Sup- pressor Must be present if the input document serial numbers are to be suppressed on output. If present, must be delimited by the special character ‚Äú>‚Äù. E6 Problem Code Sup- pressor Must be present if the edit problem codes are to be suppressed. If present, must be delimited by the special character ‚Äú>‚Äù. E7 Section Breaker Suppressor Must be present if a section breaker ‚Äú@‚Äù is not desired between sections. If present, must be delimited by the special character ‚Äú>‚Äù. E8 Section Number Suppressor Must be present if the input section numbers are to be sup- pressed on output. If present, must be delimited by the special character ‚Äú>‚Äù. E9 Field Breaker Sup- pressor Must be present if a Ô¨Åeld breaker (+) is desired between Ô¨Åelds. If present, must be delimited by the special character ‚Äú>‚Äù. E10 FRMT/SC Block Control Number Generator Must be present if the header Operator Class/Format Code and SC Block Control Number are to be generated into each document. This parameter option applies only to Non-Pipeline data. If present, must be delimited by the special character ‚Äú>‚Äù. The Operator Class/Format Code and SC Block Control Number, when generated, will follow positions 1 through 4 (character count) of each document of a block and each block header when the Non-Pipeline Block Header option is selected.

of the Document Parameters has been set to generate breakers. If present, must be delimited by the special character ‚Äú< ‚Äù. Once all desired parameters for a particular section

) Fields (

) For initial transmittal, at least one set of parameters for a Ô¨Åeld must be prepared for each section. The Edit System requires a set of Ô¨Åeld parameters for every Ô¨Åeld on input. As many as sixty Ô¨Åelds per section can be output from the Edit System. Field parameters must follow the associated section param- eters in their sequential order of occurrence.
) Field Parameters (
) Exhibit
, Field Parameters, shows the format and speciÔ¨Åcations for each Ô¨Åeld of a section. The following is a description of the various elements and options.

Element Name Instructions E1 Number of Characters Must be present for the Ô¨Årst Ô¨Åeld in a section. If present, must be delimited by a special character ‚Äú>‚Äù. Note: An alphanumeric Ô¨Åeld cannot exceed 200 characters, and a numeric (Ô¨Åeld type ‚ÄúNUME‚Äù or ‚ÄúLSGN‚Äù) cannot exceed 80 characters. E2 Field Type 1) The default parameter is ‚ÄúNUME‚Äù, which indicates that the Ô¨Åeld as entered will be numeric and not signed. Other values are:a)‚ÄúALPH‚Äù - alphanumeric b) ‚ÄúLSGN‚Äù - leading (separate character) signed numeric. 2) If present, must be delimited by the special character ‚Äú>‚Äù. 3) The data entry program prior to the edits program will zero or blank Ô¨Åll Ô¨Åelds and perform any Ô¨Åeld justiÔ¨Åcation required. 4) The edits program uses the above Ô¨Åeld type information to perform a problem code check for the presence of alpha or special characters in numeric Ô¨Åelds and to assign the leading sign over-punched data in the case of the ‚ÄúLSGN‚Äù option. E3 Mixed Field Check 1) Must be present if a check for a mixed Ô¨Åeld is desired. If present, must be delimited by the special character ‚Äú>‚Äù. 2) If a mixed data check is desired, the parameter MIXn appears where ‚Äún‚Äù is a number from 1 to 7. 3) Each iteration of ‚Äún‚Äù will allow up to four Ô¨Åelds (same section) in the previous document for the occurrence of mixed data. Example: If the social security number (SSN) and tax period both need to be checked in one section, and a re- mittance Ô¨Åeld also needs to be checked in a second section, the mixed data Ô¨Åeld parameters would be as follows: SSN would be MIX1 Tax Period would be MIX1 Remittance would be MIX2 E4 Field Parameters Completed The special character ‚Äú+‚Äù must be present once all the param- eters for a given Ô¨Åeld have been entered. To replicate Ô¨Åeld parameters for additional Ô¨Åelds, the ‚Äú+‚Äù should be followed by ‚Äún‚Äù representing the number of additional Ô¨Åelds, followed by another ‚Äú+‚Äù. Example: ‚Äú10+5+‚Äù would account for six Ô¨Åelds, each 10 char- acters long, deÔ¨Åned as ‚ÄúNUME‚Äù with no mixed Ô¨Åeld checks. page 10 3.24 ISRP System

) Once all the desired parameters for a document have been speciÔ¨Åed, the special character ‚Äú[‚Äù must be present. It must be present once for each format code. It immediately follows the special section ‚Äú
‚Äù entry shown above in IRM
, Section Parameters. (
) This section deÔ¨Ånes the responsibilities of analysts in preparing format param- eters. (

) Each format code requires a set of parameters. These parameters must be prepared by the analyst assigned to the project which processes the documents associated with that format code. A Ô¨Åle of parameters for all format codes will be maintained by the Operation Support: Information Technology: Applications Development: Submission Processing: Paper Processing Branch (OS:IT:AD:SP:PPB), the responsible section. (
) Analysts must ensure that the OS:IT:AD:SP:PPB responsible section has received the parameters for each project. (
) Parameters must be received by OS:IT:AD:SP:PPB with enough lead time for implementation prior to System Acceptability Testing (SAT) and production transmittal dates. (
) Normally transmittals will be made no more than once a week, on Wednesday. (

) Analysts should provide a memorandum to the OS:IT:AD:SP:PPB responsible section listing the following: a. Project name(s) b. Project number(s) c. Operator Class/Format Code(s) d. SAT Library version name (e.g., S
) e. SAT required dates f. SAT sites g. Production required dates h. Production sites i. Name of responsible analyst j. Organization symbols k. Telephone extensions (

) The detailed name of the UNYSIS program Ô¨Åle, including all qualiÔ¨Åers, read/ write keys, etc., must also be included. Element name(s) to be used will be Operator Class/Format Code(s) of the parameter set(s) contained in the element(s). See Exhibit
, Example of Parameters Transmittal. (

) When updating any of the parameters for a particular document, it is necessary to resubmit the entire set of parameters (document, section, and Ô¨Åeld) as the complete set of parameters for the identiÔ¨Åed Operator Class/ Format Code to be replaced on the on-line parameter Ô¨Åle. Project analysts are responsible for reviewing the correctness of all updates as well as initial trans- mittals. Edits
page
Normally transmittals will be made no more than once a week, on Wednesday.

) The detailed name of the UNYSIS program Ô¨Åle, including all qualiÔ¨Åers, read/ write keys, etc., must also be included. Element name(s) to be used will be the Operator Class/Format Code(s) of the parameter set(s) contained in the element(s). See Exhibit

) When updating any of the parameters for a particular document, it is necessary to resubmit the entire set of parameters (document, section, and Ô¨Åeld) as the complete set of parameters for the identiÔ¨Åed Operator Class/ Format Code to be replaced on the on-line parameter Ô¨Åle. Project analysts are responsible for reviewing the correctness of all updates as well as initial trans- mittals.
) Deleting Parameters (
) Project analysts are responsible for timely deletion of parameters for obsolete documents. Deletions are accomplished by parameter input as follows: Operator Class Format Code DELETE>\. (

) The Operation Support: Information Technology: Applications Development: Submission Processing: Paper Processing Branch (OS:IT:AD:SP:PPB) section responsible for maintaining the SC Edits parameter Ô¨Åle should be notiÔ¨Åed via memorandum when a set of parameters for a document is to be deleted, including the date of obsolescence. Section personnel maintaining the parameter Ô¨Åle will affect the necessary deletion. (

) The DELETE capability should not be used when updating existing param- eters. If updating parameters with the same Operator Class/Format Code, the update will overlay the old parameters and deleting is not necessary.
) Examples of the Use of Parameters (
) The following exhibits are for use as examples of parameter value only. They are not intended to describe any actual IRS document. Exhibit
, Example of Use of Parameters, provides an example of the values which may be used in parameters. A description of the expected output is listed Ô¨Årst. The parameter values are listed next.
